comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: Soon after the United States’ entry into World War I, the Food and Fuel Control Act of 1917 established the United States Food Administration, with a mandate to voluntarily reduce the domestic consumption of food and produce, while increasing home production. President Woodrow Wilson appointed future president Herbert Hoover as its head, and Hoover appointed Mrs. Mina C. Van Winkle (1875-1932) to organize and direct its speakers’ bureau. [1] A photo of. Mina C. Van Winkle (Wilhelmina ("Mina") Caroline Ginger), in her earlier role as President of Woman's Political Union of New Jersey, leading the New Jersey Women's Political Union in the "Handing On The Torch of Victory" demonstration, on August 7, 1915, is on Flickr Commons: "Suffrage tug, Jersey City (LOC)"                       by Bain / The Library of Congress
